description:
The food, the service, and the chef are all amazing!

Prices are reasonable; it's San Francisco; chill the füçk out, people.

Love the different fruit mimosas.

We'll be back again and again.
author: Cyrus N.

description:
Amazing Filipino brunch pop-up! They do a very contemporary take on some traditional filipino dishes, but they also have the very comforting silogs. Love that they throw in a twist or two here and there by adding cotton candy, 63 eggs, or caviar. It's a bit over the top, but in a good way. Gotta dress it up for the hipsters and foodies in SF! 

The only ding (minus a star) was that the shaved ice in the halo halo was a bit too course and hard rather than fluffy. Other than that, the flavors were amaazing and plating was beautiful!!
author: Audrey L.

description:
I actually tried to dine here when they first opened years ago,  but left because after we were seated, we were ignored for 10 minutes. I wanted to give them another chance as I was craving for some Filipino food. My friend and I came for Sunday brunch on a Sunday around 11am. We were able to get a seat with no problems. The service has definitely improved.  The restaurant also started filling up shortly after.
 
Foods:
Lumpia - we thought that this was good. The sauce that it came with was really bomb. The green sauce they have on the counters was also really tasty! We were wondering what was in it

Lechon Kawali - crispy pork belly with mango-tomato salad, shaved jalapeños  and steamed rice - This dish was nicely presented but we thought that the pork could have been hotter as it was a little warm

Combo Silog - this dish came with Ticino, Longganisa, tapa, and garlic fried rice with an egg on top- we thought this dish was average

My friend is Filipino and thought that this place was okay. Nothing really stood out but it was still good. This is the only Filipino place in the sunset so if you're really craving flip food, def check this brunch place out. The presentation is on point and def IGable.
author: Daniel S.

description:
More like a 3.5 but I've rounded up to 4 because I think my experience was definitely better than a 3.

My friends and I arrived at about 12 on a Saturday afternoon and were seated in about 15 minutes. It's a relatively small place and their hours are very limited so I'd be prepared to wait about 10-15min. 

Between the three of us, we ordered lumpia, combo silog, and the lechon as well as a halo halo for dessert. The lumpia was nice and crisp but I've had better elsewhere. The combo silog was tasty but so felt that the beef was a little too dry for my taste and was probably my least favorite of what we ordered - the garlic rice was really good though! My favorite though was the lechon, so nice and crispy without being overly fatty; I also really liked the sweet slaw under. This dish was also beautifully presented! As for the halo halo, it was a crowd pleaser- but when is it not? 

Overall it was a good meal and while I wasn't blown away by anything this time, I'd love to come back and try some of the other dishes!
author: Janice L.

description:
Only a weekend pop-up at the moment? 
Malasa seems permently a pop-up at this craw station at the moment. Open only on the weekend brunch time while craw station is closed. Good use of space I think.
Since I dined with a large group I was able to try out a bunch of their dishes. 

Recs: chicharron, cheese sticks, lumpia, corn beef and eggplant 

Server was attentive and also surveyed us when we were done with our meal. Wanted to know if we'd attend an actual Malasa location. Not just a popup
author: Liz N.

description:
This is a filipino pop-up shop style restaurant that is only open a few hours around brunch time. It's in the inner sunset and we had to wait around 45 minutes before being seated, since it is a pretty small restaurant. Luckily, there was a farmer's market north of the restaurant that we got to kill some time at.

I went with a friend and we split three dishes.

First, we had the Lumpia Shanghai for an appetizer which is an egg roll with ground pork and shrimp and comes with a sweet and sour mango sauce. This was pretty good, but I think it tasted better with the savory, green sauce that they have on the table. This was a good sized appetizer and satisfied us until we got our meal. At this point it was around 1:30 and we were pretty hungry at this point.

Next we had the Tinapang Bangus which is a smoked boneless baby milk fish with caviar, garlic fried rice and an egg. The milk fish is a fish you can eat in it's entirety which is pretty good. The fish was prepared lightly so you can still taste the fish! I think it was smoked just enough to bring out the flavor, but the balance of the dish could've improved because I thought the salad was too acidic.

Finally, we had the combination sisilog. This is a traditional filipino breakfast and came with sweet pork, pork sausage and dried beef. I really enjoyed all the meats, but the sweet pork was probably my favorite. I've had sisilog that was better at other restaurants, I'd say this place's sisilog was decent and enjoyable.

I also enjoyed the vibe because it was pretty relaxing, wasn't that loud or a lot of people there. A ton of families came and it seemed like a filipino spot that people enjoyed! We need more of these in SF!
author: Christopher L.

description:
Decent brunch, but I think service leaves much to be desired. We came early, right as they opened, and even though every other table was open,  the hostess wanted to seat our 2 person party with another 2 person party at a 4 person, combined table. Her explanation was that she was 'expecting a lot of people'. They attempted this with another couple half an hour later, even though there were plenty of open tables available, and they asked to be reseated at the bar... Lol. The restaurant was just barely starting to fill up by the time we finished our meals and left, so I'm not sure why they have this policy for placing strangers together at the same table, and I wonder where all the people they were expecting went.

Anyway, I haven't had a lot of Filipino food, but I enjoyed both the Arroz a la Cubana which I ordered and the Carne Norte that my friend had. I think mine was a bit more unique given the combination of savory and sweet flavors and the pepper cotton candy, but both were quite tasty and we pretty much licked our plates clean! If you are a fan of savory brunches, this would be a good brunch place to try. I'm not sure about their selection of sweet brunch items though. 

Of note, my friend was quite disappointed with the presentation of our food as previous Yelp photos indicated that dishes were decorated with edible flowers, but these were missing from our orders.
author: Sherry L.

description:
Looking for a brunch place? Phillipino food in the Sunset? Look no further Malasa is the place.  Malasa started as a pop up and turned into a place locals love.  They share the same space as the Craw Station on 9th Avenue.  The catch is if you want to come to Malasa you have to come on Saturday and Sundays.

The "manager", Ro, is awesome! They were slammed when I visited, but she took the time to chat and make recommendations.  I ordered the chicken chicharon, the crane norte, and sisig as recommended.  I was not disappointed.

Love the vibe of Malasa.  Will back again.
author: Peter C.

description: The hostess/waitress was very friendly and gave good recommendations for appetizers. I enjoyed the food and drinks. She checked up on me a few times to make sure I was good. She even gave me a complimentary mango drink to go! I made sure to give her a good tip for great customer service.
author: Sam Y.

description:
I have been meaning to come here ever since the bf moved to the inner sunset, this past weekend, we FINALLY made it, and mm it did not disappoint.

Malasa is Filipino brunch heaven! Upon my first look at the menu, there was so many things I wanted to order, my eyes were definitely bigger than my stomach. After much contemplation, we ended up ordering lumpia (DUH), the carne norte, and the combination silog which includes tocino, longganisa, and tapa. Literally, everything was so delicious. Only thing was our lumpia came a bit after our food, so we thought they might have forgotten it, but the server even apologized that it took a bit longer, so it was no biggie at all.

My bf and I thought the servings would be kind of small, but we were wrong, we left full, and satisfied with leftovers for the following morning. Overall, I definitely recommend everyone to check out Malasa. I will 100% be returning to try out other items I was eyeing from the menu.  Staff and food were both amazing!
author: Nina W.

description:
Malasa is located inside Crawstation. Inside is pretty small, but thankfully, it wasn't too busy when my gf and I went. 

We got the mango mimosas, lumpias and silogs. The mango mimosas honestly tasted like the canned mango juice you get in pacific super added on top of champagne. It was a tad bit too sweet for our liking.

The lumpias were great. It was nice a crispy and well packed with filling inside. These lumpias were not dripping in oil which made it easy to go through.

My girlfriend got the Longanisa silog while I got the combo silog. The Beef was very dry and it made me feel like I was eating beef jerky. The longanisa was great though. It went well with the garlic fried rice. The papaya salad on the side was light and refreshing. The tomatoes on the side had a nice yolky flavor.
author: Timothy C.

description: Stumbled across this pop-up after a nice lil Tuesdate at SF Botanical Garden.  From my understanding it's a partner joint between Malala x Craw Station.  Decided to check it out for a light meryenda.  Fast and friendly service.  We were seated right away and didn't have to wait long for our food.  We ordered the Fried Cheese Sticks and Fried Fish Balls.  Both were good, nothing special.  I left here feeling satiated but the experience kinda left me hoping for more.  Of course it didn't compare to the authentic food back home but still, good food and great service here.  Might seem overpriced but that's just the price of SF for ya.
author: Jezhra S.

description:
Definitely recommend giving this place a try!!

Came here on a Sunday morning, around 11am and was seated immediately as there was no line. 

I ordered the carne norte which consisted of tender flavorful chunks of corned beef brisket meat (and some chunks of fat) with some onions tomato and potatoes all over a pile of buttery garlicky fried rice. This was all topped with a fried egg and some sliced onion. This dish was suuuper rich, from the fattiness of the meat and the buttery-ness of the rice, the onion definitely helped cut some of the grease. Overall, it was good but I do wish there were less chunks of fat and more chunks of meat though. 

My boyfriend got the tortang talong which was an omelette with slices of chinese eggplant topped with bonito flakes, rolls of crispy seaweed, and a sauce all over a pile of garlic fried rice. The eggplant and the omelette itself was kind of bland, wish it was salted more or seasoned. The bonito flakes, seaweed definitely add a nice crunch and texture to the dish.

Service was friendly, nice atmosphere, highly recommend!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Delicious gourmet authentic Filipino food.
All I could say I wish I could eat more than I could when I went to this restaurant. 

The Carne Norte Corned Beef was so good and it wasn't even my plate. The beef was tasty, juicy, soft that it melts in your mouth feeling. Topped with fried egg! Can't ask for anything else.

Toccino breakfast plate was yummy too because I've had so much toccino in my Filipino born in the Philippines life that I know a good toccino and this is one of them. It was right amount of fat and meat and the marinade was balanced not too sweet, not salty. Also topped with fried egg. 

The calamansi Juice was so good it just took me back to good old time when I used to live in the Philippines and they would make freshly squeezed calamansi juice which gives lots of vitamin c.

This is one of the places that I have to go back to whenever I visit SF again. It's a small restaurant but I seriously know it's worth the wait if it gets crowded.

HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!
author: Sarlyn P.

description:
This is a great place for brunch on the weekends. 

The dishes were delicious and the people were nice. The food had the feel of being homemade and comfort food but elevated with beautiful touches by Dino, the Chef. He sprinkled his dishes with lots of details and his love for his food showed. They were nothing short of works of art, edible art. For drinks, we loved the pineapple mango juice and Bloody Mary. 

Conveniently located near the N Judah Muni line, the Inner Sunset Sunday's Flea Market, and the Inner Sunset Farmers Market. It could get crowded so there could be a wait but it is worth it.
author: Yelp R.

description:
Oh my gosh I love this place. When will Malasa have its own standing restaurant because I crave their eggplant omelet not only on weekends but on weekdays too!!

I have been here twice and both times I was served by the warmest, kindest servers--they're so genial it really feels like I'm eating at a friend's home rather than a pop-up restaurant. My first time at Malasa, my friend and I got the combination plate and the eggplant omelet to share and omg the omelet is SO GOOD!! I really love omelets and I also really love eggplant so the combination in addition to a talented chef and the okonomiyaki-like seasoning on top killed me... in a good way. I am in love. You can guess what I got the next time I visited. 

I had work on the weekends for the longest time which broke my heart because I always missed Malasa's pop-up hours, but now that I have my weekends back I will be posting up at this brunch spot all. the. time.
author: Anna L.

description: I was really excited to come back for their carne Norte but I left with a sour impression of their customer service. We came in as a party of three and the server instructed us that it would be a 15 min wait. So my party and I strolled around the farmers market and came back to empty tables. The server told us she would be seating us shortly.. 15 mins later with those empty tables still available, we were still waiting outside. It felt like the server just ignored us. I started looking around and noticed a couple of tables were just waiting to take their order. The whole wait time was almost 40 minutes. My party and I could not wait any longer so we crossed our names out and left. I'm just really appalled that we could not be seated despite having tables available with a promise of that we were all going to be seated (my party and another party were told so at the same time) but that party was immediately seated and filled up one of the available tables while we waited an additional 15 mins. Maybe it was a busy day but there was just a lack of communication when we were told twice that we would be seated immediately with no follow up. What a bummer though because their carne norte is really delicious and tender!
author: Sarah F.

description: Your typical but not so typical Filipino eats.  My family had brunch at Malasa and enjoyed their play on Filipino breakfast favorites.  Their corned beef was excellent, with just  enough garlic fried rice, accompanied by fried egg.  We also had their tapa, longganisa, and tocino - lots of meat that went well with a vinegrette like table sauce.  Good food, fast service!
author: Angie V.

description: Swung by Malasa this morning- I've always seen people strolling around the Inner Sunset with delicious looking food (from Malasa) and I finally got the chance to try it today! My coworker & i ordered the tortang talong & carne norte-  both were delicious! Ro, the manager and the girl at the register were both very friendly. After I got my food (to go) a line started to form. The kitchen looked very well staff and the wait time for food to go was ten min- very reasonable and def would come back!
author: Chantel Y.

description:
3.5 stars!
A pop-up restaurant located in Crawstation in the Inner Sunset, Malasa offers tasty, Filipino-inspired brunch dishes on weekends! The dishes here are beautifully plated and are of good quality and have balanced yet bold flavors, though the portion sizes are somewhat small for the prices.

We started our brunch with the combination silog, a plate of garlic fried rice, a fried egg, sides of green papaya and tomato, and three different meats: the slightly sweet tocino (caramelized pork), a sweet pork sausage called longganisa, and thinly-sliced, dried beef called tapa. The tapa was my favorite of the three, as it was lean, salty, and had a great texture!

We continued with the arroz caldo, a rice porridge served with a Chinese donut, chicken, and a hard-boiled egg. The porridge was so tasty, and the crunchy elements in the warm mixture added a great textural contrast! We also had the smoked trout, served with lumpfish caviar, scallions, and more garlic fried rice, and again, everything about this dish was so nicely balanced and delicious!

Finally, though we had ordered the lumpia shanghai appetizer, the server must have forgotten it, but it was brought out to us after we asked again--these fried, crispy egg rolls were decent, though they only had a small amount of the pork and shrimp filling. They were served with a sweet and sour "apple-sour cherry gastrique" on the side, which balanced out the savoriness nicely!

Overall, Malasa was a decent place to have a unique Filipino take on brunch, though I wouldn't say that it's worth going out of the way to try. While everything was decently tasty, the prices were quite high, and the service could have been a little more attentive.
author: David K.

description:
Great food! Came here last Sunday and we ordered the arroz ala cubana, tinapang Bangus, fried chicken skin and fish balls.

All dishes we delicious. The arroz oddly had cotton candy on top of it but it turned out to be really good.

Only reason why I'm not giving 5 stars is that the service could've been better. Food came out a little slow and one of the servers asked us smilingly on ordering another appetizer and dessert, and both times we respectfully said no thank you, and both times she frowned at us afterwards. 

The chef/cook also came to our table twice because he forgot a garnish on two of our dishes. But at least he was nice about it unlike the servers.
author: Gino T.

description:
Very Delicious!
I was jonesing for Flip Food. Had my fill of Michelin Star Restaurants...and needed some comfort Food.
Thank gosh Malasa was a go to destination already on the calendar!
 
We had Calamansi and Mango Mimosas, Lumpia, Fried Cheese, Lechon, Corned Beef, Eggplant omelet, Arroz Caldo. 
The owners of the restaurant brought us complimentary dessert (banana egg rolls and ice cream topped with cotton candy) and it was so delicious too! 

The chef, Dino was engaging and talkative. Hospitality was great!
A go to place for those craving Filipino food!
author: Joy D.

description:
EVENT: we love b-lunchin' and looking for something tastayyy... like super tastassyy! Heard this place through some friends and it's been on the "to try places" just for 1 day... and I had to come here... cause the pics looks soooo good!!!

It's a little cute pop-up restaurant - only open Saturday and Sunday only... *sad face* 

PARKING: It's always possible to find parking - free parking, just park a couple blocks away! It might be good cause it's a filling meal! Need to walk that cholesterol out!

SERVICE: Sweet people here! We're early risers ... got here at like 9:50am. They start serving at 10am. We still got sat down and they served us water. So, it was great! We had time to look at the menu and decide what I want - but it was the longest wait ever! Food came out a tad bit slow... maybe cause I'm like super excited plus hungry!

FOOD:
(1) Lumpia: little egg rolls served in a house sweet and sour sauce - super tasty. 5 stars!
(2) Arroz caldo: rice porridge, eggs, green onions, chicken, and served with a crispy Asian donut. Yes! The best is dipping the crispy donut into the porridge! MMm! 5 stars
(3) Combination: sampler of all 3 meats! Beef, sweet pork, and sausage - got to try every thing!!! Served with garlicky rice topped with a delicious fried sunny side up egg and a little corner of papaya salad! 5 stars!

DRINKS:
(1) Mango mimosa - fresh mangoesss!! Now, we're drinking!

DESSERT:
(1) Halo-Halo: one of my favorite desserts in the world! The ice-cream is excellent and omg the multi-colored and flavor jelly is the BEST! 5 stars!

**MUST GET: Arroz Caldo! 5 starss!!

**OVERALL: I will be back for MORE!!! SEE Y'ALL there! 5 stars!
author: Mindy Y.

description:
1-sentence takeaway: solid Filipino food with beautiful presentation.

Crispy Chicken Chicharron
As a kid, I used to be the one who stole all the fried chicken skin from our KFC outings. As an adult, I'm delighted to have this prepared by itself.  Deliciously savory, perfectly crisp, and LOVED the spicy kick of the hot sauce.

Smoked Trout
Smoked trout, a 63 degree C egg, and lumpfish caviar artfully arranged over garlic fried rice.  Flavors really popped and the dish was truly stunning to look at.

Carne Norte
Corned beef brisket + potatoes and onions (like a corned beef hash) with a fried egg over garlic fried rice.  Perfect comfort food!  Fried egg was an amazing combination of crispy egg white edges with a gooey yolk.

Service was overall very friendly, but a bit scattered.  Docking a star for miscellaneous issues: 1.) no appetizer plates provided so we were both angling to not make a mess of the crispy chicken skin on the table, 2.) for both ordering and getting the bill, we had to try several times to wave someone down, 3.) one piece of the chicken skin had many little feather remnants which made it a little unappetizing despite being assured it was edible.  All that said, I would absolutely go back.
author: Sheila C.

description:
For what you pay: Great price.  Delicious food.  Woohoo!  Love it
Ambiance: Kind of small, waits are worth it. 
Service: Obviously short staffed so understandably our drinks were slow as was the check.  Not a huge deal
Taste: Makes up for the rest. Amazing.  Such a taste that one is not quick to forget!  

There are long waits to get seated, to get service and to get food but you WILL be given reason to disregard these irking qualities. This pop up Filipino brunch place is magnificent where it counts most: they make amazing food.  Unique to its culture, and inconspicuous in the bay area, this is some of the best Filipino food I have ever had.

The chef is most admirable in his attempts to tailor your food to your liking.  Eating off the menu is hard for vegans: most options have egg or meat in it.  The closest thing I saw was the vegetarian Tortang Talong which had egg in it.

I asked the waitress if she could do the Tortang Talong omelette without the egg; making it vegan friendly.  The chef came to my table and asked if I would like it spicy, confirmed that I could have no animal product in it and assured me he would whip something up. He gave me a maniacal smile and ran back to the kitchen.  I trusted it would be good by the genial whim in his attitude.  He looked excited for the challenge. 

Just like that the Tortang Talong omelette was reinvented into a vegan friendly stuffed eggplant with a piquant spicy sauce.  If you are vegan, first of all, order this and also ask for a side of rice.  

Overall, the ability of the staff to curtail this dish to my dietary restrictions was most auspicious and aggrandized the places' merit in my mind.  

My order here was off menu, which can be inconvenient at times, but the cooking staff was very accommodating to my eating restrictions and did not make me feel forced into ordering a typical entree.  On top of that, this was one of the best stuffed eggplants I have ever had.  The ingenuity and flexibility of the chefs culinary art is respectable and frankly, delicious.  I have never had any stuffed eggplant that was spiced this way. Incredibly delicious.  

My friends all thoroughly enjoyed their meals.  My wife devoured the combination platter, a medley of three meats, rice and eggs.

Street parking.
 
Open weekends only.

Bathroom in back.
author: Rob C.

description:
Delicious Filipino food! I was concerned at first that it would be too 'westernized', but it was amazingly authentic.

Try the SILOG combo! Comes with silog (sigang=garlic fried rice + itlog=sunny side up egg), and 3 different meats: tapa (sirloin beef steak), tocino (pork belly), and longaniza (sweet sausage).

My boyfriend could not stop eating their yummy Carne Norte dish (Filipino beef brisket/ 'corned beef' with potatoes, egg, and garlic fried rice)!
author: Vera Marie J.

description:
An extremely amazing Filipino brunch spot! It's a popup at crawstation on weekends and I feel bad for anyone who misses out in it!

Came here in recommendation by my family and wasn't expecting anything special except maybe something comparable to the silogs you get at a typical Filipino restaurant but boy was I wrong! The chef puts lots of care into what he makes and not only offers a delicious meal but a reminiscent breakfast experience in its own. Are you getting that Costco canned corned beef over leftover garlic rice? No way! I was skeptical, but I was borderline wishing I could order a second plate. We ordered a plate of kare-kare to share, which I'm usually not a fan of, but this was an exception, which included a bagoong reduction that cut through the peanut butter taste. (Amazing) 

The chef offered to let us try an octopus adobo he was working on. It's a drier and stickier type of adobo, which the octopus was cooked down to something almost jerky-like and was extremely flavorful, down to the addition of scallops and potatoes. Not on the menu yet, but honored to try it! Everyone is extremely friendly here and I had a great experience at Malasa.
author: Krysta M.

description:
Food is just okay.  Overhyped and overpriced for what it is.  The size of the portions don't make up for it either.  It seems like other reviews are extra-excited b/c there aren't many other Filipino options around.  But let's be honest:  how does it really taste?  Does it do well in representing Filipino cuisine?  I don't know, but the combination sisig....

The tocino was slightly too sweet, but it wasn't bad.  It actually is quite good for the flavor of syrupy-sauced bbq pork, but the flavor becomes too repetitive after half the tocino portion is gone and you need something salty to change things up.  Salty, you ask?  DIVE INTO THE BEEF TAPA!  You get what's like beef jerky marinated in salt!!!  Do not fear, it's supposed to be this way!  You were warned!  Ah, now you are thirsty, it's okay, the water is FREEEE!  Alternating with portions of tocino to offset what is the cube of salt that goes into each forkful of tapa beef, we move onto the longganisa... but wait, what does it taste like?  I had this dish a couple of weeks ago.  This item was not memorable, sorry!  I wasn't overwhelmed by salt - no, not at all.  Back to the beef tapa!!!  Just buy a bag of tough beef jerky, dip it in some salt, then try to tear away at it.  Swallow quickly to avoid the cube of salt from dissolving in your mouth.  If this is what you're into, the tapa will be the most memorable part of your meal!  

Separately, the order of lumpia is a child-sized appetizer for two; or adult-sized for one!  Perfect, I love to eat alone!  A great deal at an outrageous price of $8?  HMM, increase the portion ($8 for 5 or 6 tiny pieces of lumpia?), or drop the price!  At this price, it should at least be wrapped in bacon sprinkled with flecks of gold and blessed by a monk.  What?  Outrageous, yeah?  Anyway, quality of food... I normally love lumpia, but let's call this one "limpia" for the level of flaccidity.  Do yourself a favor and get some frozen ones from the store and pan-fry (not deep-fry you say?) it yourself; it will be about the same or better than what I'd experienced at Malasa.

Okay let's be serious, just don't order the combination silog and try something else.  If you feel like donating a few bucks, order the limpia.  From my experience, I won't be back to try the other items.
author: Sean H.

description:
My boyfriend and I dropped into Malasa, as we were starving and the Korean BBQ spot nearby only had all-you-can-eat meals available. We are so stoked that we found this place. Apparently, the owner used to be the main sushi chef at Blowfish! Anyway, this was some of the tastiest  Filipino food I've had in a long time and I will definitely be back in the future. 
Recommended: lumpia, the silog combo meat plate with rice & fried egg, the arroz caldo, mango mojitos and duhhh ube ice cream. :)
author: M. F.

description: I have known and followed Chef Dino for years and his food is amazing. Malasa is no exception. The meal I had here has been the singular highlight of my culinary experience in San Francisco. The care and passion he has for the food he serves is evident in the food and his personality. I highly recommend you try everything on the menu. I tried. And I am coming back for more.
author: Julian C.

description: I was looking forward to going to this restaurant for lunch. I've never had an owner call me and then talk to the chef at the same time while he's at the farmers market just to plan our meal!  A couple of my friends are Vegan & the owner, Ro, made sure that the chef can accommodate them & made tofu sisig! You just have to call a few days in advance so they can get the ingredients ahead of time. The service was amazing, accommodating & the food didn't disappoint! My husband liked the lechon kawali & I got the pork belly sisig with side of atchara. My friends were impressed with the food presentation, taste & service. We'll definitely come back again. Glad we made a reservation coz there was a long waiting list when we got there.
author: Renee S.

description:
FINALLY! A Filipino restaurant on the westside of town! Granted it's only open on the weekends, but I'll take what I can get. And bonus - they do Filipino cuisine well! 

If you're new to Filipino food, I would order the combination silog plate and try all of the yummy meats. My personal favorite is the Arroz Caldo (rice porridge) for cold, foggy days and the corned beef when you want to go into a food coma on a Sunday afternoon. My go-to drink is the mango-melon cooler (with free re-fills!). 

There's ample space and it hasn't been too busy the couple of times I've went. They have a sizeable, enclosed back patio which was a nice surprise. This place will sure to get bumpin' though, so make a reservation just in case.
author: Dyanna Q.

description: Had a great brunch here. Loved the melon juice stuff and the wait staff was super helpful
author: Andrew B.

description: I had the bangus and it was really delicious! Service was great too! Look forward to eating here again when I come to SF.
author: Charlene C.

description: Family lunch... great service and great food. The weather today is really cold and so is the restaurant. I wish they had a heater lol. Even though it's bit cold, the food was worth it. My favorite was their sour pepper sauce that always goes with all Filipino dishes and the fried chicken skin. Their corn beef brisket hash over rice and fried egg is good and I'll request extra fried egg next time too. I'm more of a poached egg fan over the dish which maybe in the future they will have it. Beside it's per preference. Everyone's tastebud is different. The roast pork belly over garlic rice is good and maybe it will be better in small bit size. Overall I love it .. everything is great. I'm picky but I give restaurants benefit of the doubt and this place is really good. Oh yeah would I come back? Of course. I want to try their other beautiful dishes.
author: Christy V.

description:
The owners of this little gem make great partners! Both friendly and helpful in explaining the menu.

Food was delicious and presentation above par!

Highly recommended!
author: Rina E.

description:
One of my favorite brunch places in the city!! 

Delicious Filipino food-- the Carne Norte is my go to. The combination silog is really good as well. Food presentation is great. 

Service is excellent -- people are very friendly and make you feel at home. Chef Dino is not only talented but also very kind and down to earth. 

Little to no wait time for the times I've been there. Highly recommend checking this place out!
author: Erika H.

description:
I've been to this quaint homey place 5 or  6 times already for Brunch.  My friend Vivica always book this place for us when friends get-together on weekends or celebrate a birthday.

The warm reception we received from the hosts/staff/owners hasn't changed since day 1.  It feels like we just hanged out in our neighbor's place.

The food is amazing!  It's authentic Filipino food at it's finest.  I have never seen a Filipino food presented in a fancy, elegant & sassy way comparable to those of Michelin starred restaurants.  They made the food look so tempting without sacrificing the quality of taste.  I'm so impressed.  Try their home made Carne Norte (Corn Beef), Arroz Caldo, their Crispy Lechon Kawali. Yum!

Next time I have to check the other menu on board on a regular day since on weekends it's only Filipino Brunch.

Highly recommended.
author: Suri D.

description:
So good!! Came here for brunch on Saturday with two friends. I was confused at first when I arrived and saw the sign said Crawstation, and double-checked the address. Yup, I was at the right place. It's Malasa@Crawstation on the weekends. The place was filled when we got there around 1PM, but luckily a table had just cleared up, so there was no need to wait in line.

Two of us decided to order the combination platter and my other friend ordered the carne norte. My only complaint is that the food took over twenty minutes to arrive. I was so hungry I gobbled it up in seconds. Overall the platter was good. The egg was fried perfectly, and I liked the garlic fried rice. The longanisa was my favorite of the meats. My friend also ordered the Calamansi drink, which was sort of like Filipino lemonade and it was very refreshing. The carne norte also tasted good. It was a little on the pricier side, as our dishes were all over $10. 

Definitely would come back here, and wish they weren't only open on weekends!
author: Christina G.

description: Good Filipino food is hard to find. A lot of Filipino restaurants are too greasy and cut corners. The chef at Malasa is so meticulous, I saw him carefully review each plate before it goes out. Skip the silogs unless you're really craving for one. I grew up and love tocilogs and tapsilogs, I got the combo silog and asked them to hold the longganisa and they gave more tapa and tocino. Yes, it was good but didn't blow me away as it's kind of like the basic Filipino breakfast food. Go for one of the brunch specials, they are what propelled Masala to my 5 star review. The Arroz a la Cubana is the most instagramable dish there, it has a cloud of sweet and savory cotton candy that deflates with the warmth of the dish. The ground beef with sofrito brings me back to childhood memories. The banana turon was also excellent, sometimes people caramelize too much sugar on the turon and you just get one note of sweet, Masala does a light caramelization on the turon and also serves it with a cloud of cotton candy and vanilla ice cream.
author: Rey L.

description:
Cute, pop-up restaurant that serves traditional Filipino breakfast and brunch. Curious that it is only open Saturday and Sunday; We came on a weekend and there was surprisingly a very short line. We ordered the: 

Combination plate // A combination of Beef Tapa, Tocino, Longganisa, and a fried egg on top of garlic rice. A good option if you're looking to try variety of Filipino favorites. 

Longganisa // Generous portion of Filipino-style sausages. Longganisa is known for its distinctly sweet taste. Comes with a fried egg on top of garlic rice. 

Bottomless Mango-Pineapple Cooler // Definitely way too sweet. Had to dilute with ice-water to stomach it. A bit disappointing and not worth the $5. I'd go with the Calamansi next time. 

The staff are incredibly welcoming and attentive and embody classic Filipino hospitality. Overall, great service, great food and a great reminder of home.
author: Arielle I.

description:
Cheese sticks 5/10 - interesting. Not sure what kind of cheese they used but maybe American? I personally was not a fan of the cheese. The date bacon aioli was alright. Interesting. Slightly sweet. Good standard bacon flavor. 


Silog combination plate 6/10
Solid meats but nothing special. The garlic rice is delicious. The tomato thing on the side, can live without it. 


Carne Norte 7/10
Good corned beef. Not too salty. Good garlic rice. Chunks of fat is delicious. Potato is a good addition. 

Overall, really fatty meal. Nothing wrong with any of the food just not amazing as I thought it would be. Solid.
author: J P.

description: A pop up restaurant on the weekends from 10-2. The restaurant is small but so worth it. Food comes fast and service is on point in every way. I ordered the corn beef wth egg and garlic rice. The size the flavor and price is all great. Everyone is friendly and nice.
author: Steven W.

description:
The food here is decent, definitely better elsewhere in the city (personally prefer Tselogs in the tenderloin), 

Breakdown of our order: 
-combo silog - meh
-tocino - dry 
-smoked trout -  meh
-calamansi mimosa - lacking

**red flag: all the garnishes on each of our plates had been on there for so long by the time they got to us, they were cooked, refer to images** 

**The main problem here is the service. We had the unfortunate circumstance of being a complete table of asians sitting next to a complete table of white patrons. There was a gaping disparity in the way our server Kristina had treated us compared to the table next to us. It's really rare and sad thing to see in SF where certain customers are prioritized over others based on race/ethnicity. We waited for over 20 minutes for our food which came to us lukewarm at best, not once was our water refilled, whereas she was curt with our table, she was warm and informative to the adjacent table, and while we waited for the check, the other table had coffee refills, water refills, and their table cleared before we even got our check (while all plates were still on our table). 

Safe to say I wont be back. Very sad to see a place with so much potential perform like this.
author: Shelly M.

description:
I visited the bay a couple weeks ago and wanted to get my Filipino food fix.

Food: really good! The portions aren't too crazy, so you don't hate yourself. I got the combination of tapa, tocino, and longanisa. I also had their guava mango juice and THAT WAS BOMB. Only downside was that I wanted more but the waitresses were so busy that by the time they got to me I was ready to just pay and leave.

The space is kinda small. We had our duffel bags with us because we were headed to the airport after and they had to be placed right under our feet. I was also so close to the people sitting next to us that we were hearing everyone's personal conversations and vice versa.

However, it was still a great place and I definitely would come back.
author: Joy Erika D.

description:
Filipino food I've had in the past has been either hit or miss but always heavy. Finally, a place where the food is satisfying without the heaviness. Definitely recommend checking out this place on the weekend for brunch. Just make sure to bring plenty of patience to deal with parking (or take public transit or lyft/uber) and to wait for getting seated/get your order/get your food. 

4.5 for eats
Chicken chicharon - amazing! flavorful without being greasy. great hot sauce! i could eat these all day
Ticino silog - tender pork that wasn't overly fatty or heavy. 
Smoked trout - amazing dish! from the sous vide egg to the fish skin and tomato salsa. trout was a bit dry, but still flavorful. My only know would be on the garlic rice. The rice was a bit dry and not as flavorful as I expected, but the egg and other flavors really helped make up the difference
Calamansi juice - wee!

3.5 for service
While quite friendly, it was sloooow. By the time we got there, the restaurant was half empty and stayed half empty. I can't imagine how slow things would be at full capacity.
author: Judy C.

description:
Malasa is a popup@Crawstation on the weekends. impossible to spot on a driveby, a walkby yes. menu resembles Filipino fare (silogs). the trout, etc. never seen before so i skipped. .

popup happens a few hours on the weekends, hopping the whole time. Mahalo down the street nada. small space. choose a seat at the bar. wasn't ignored. asked many times by different associates how i was doing. one seen me before.

eats:combo silog (11.50) tapa, tocina, longannisa
-meats tender, alternatively sweet, salty, depending on the protein. no chewy, gristle issue.
-garlic rice not so much, maybe my expectation is overblown. (garlic breathe is for real)
-egg overfried, almost burnt. that's how SF wants it. so runny yolks must be asked for.
got a redo. the attention tweaked my attention. finally,  a server said she recognized me, ran details of our first encounter, wanted to comped me  a drink
-told her i wouldn't refuse. but there's no necessity.
-food pricer than average Filiipino spot. protein is made in house, unknown about typical Filipino place.

drink: mango cooler? (comped)
-yummy, tasty, sugary, probably would pass re sugar content.

takeouts:
-knowing Masala is legit, i would try "new" offerings next time.
-service is really great, true for everyone, not just me. cashiers mingle and bus tables too.
-parking an issue in this area.
-pricier fare, worth it-heathier food.
author: Victor G.

description:
Chef Dino elevates Filipino food in San Francisco. His heritage and culinary experience brings the culture to the next level.

The food taste great and his presentation truly makes traditional Filipino food pleasing to the eyes and tastebuds. 

He has all the traditional Filipino breakfast silogs. But will recommend the brunch menu instead. 

Special note: most of the dishes taste good with his "vinegar concoction" 

Smoked Trout is his own spin on smoked milkfish. The fish is complemented by a lump fish caviar, 63 degrees egg, crispy fish skin, eggplant salad and fried rice (making me hungry again). Try with his vinegar mix. 

Arroz caldo with brown buttered chicken, crispy chicken ski, Chinese donut and some scallion makes a Filipino congee a culinary experience. (calamasi would make this over the top). 

Tortang talong - egg plant omelet with Bonito flakes, seaweed and jufran glaze is perfect. (use his Sriracha sweet soy sauce) 

Corned beef (not from the can) is mouth watering. Chopped onion and garlic fried rice. (again use the vinegar concoction) 

Then to top it all do not forget the ice cream "Halo halo" with rice crispies.... Yeah I ate all these in one sitting,with the help of Fanny and my friend Jim.
author: SFoodie P.

description: Delicious filipino food, with a hint of fusion thrown in there. They might only be open on the weekends..so very glad we caught them open. Its a small place, but worth the wait!
author: Krista S.

description: On a Saturday the bf and I decided to check out a new spot...since he's Filipino I think he had higher expectation then I, it was busy but we were able to grab a table..the food is all home made so you couldn't go wrong with anything on the menu,I went with the combo which gives you a sample of each meats and the bf went with the fish,the chicken skin app was delicious as well...the location/pop is craw station and you should definitely check them out and support them,is the sea of American breakfast and all types of Vietnamese/Chinese restaurants it's good to see something different on he neighborhood
author: jonathan h.

description: I loved this place.  Messaged them through yelp to make a reservation and one of the owners texted me back quickly.  The place is kitchy and homie.  The workers are friendly and the service was pretty good considering the ratio of workers to customers.  The food was delicious.  Authentic and well-priced for the most part.  I expected more lechon kawali for the price, but hey, no one should be eating too much of that though, know what I'm saying?  they even brought out a turon dessert with cotton candy fluff on top for my friend's birthday.  So sweet, I definitely wanna go back and try their corned beef brisket and other entree's.
author: Edward M.

description:
Pop-up brunch!! Absolutely amazing dining experience! Delicious food, appealing presentation, the owner and chef are the nicest people! We had smoked trout, egg omelet over rice with katsuobushi, arroz caldo, fried chicken skin (two orders), corn beef over rice, halo-halo. We loved everything. Price is extremely reasonable for the flavor, quality, portion, and presentation of the food. 
Beverage was excellent too, i ordered mango cantaloupe juice, refreshing and refillable!!! My husband order watermelon juice, perfect to mix with soju and sure they have it available! It was a prefect brunch, and My husband loved it so much that we are celebratinging his bday here this year. 
We will definitely go back for it next week, wish it opens more than just weekend lunch. We will go back for the crawfish during regular time as well!!
author: Fanny Z.

description:
Chef Dino is the man! He and his lady welcomed my lady and me in true traditional Filipino fashion. We arrived for brunch on a Saturday and was quickly seated. We ordered the kalamansi mimosa, cheese sticks, chicharon chicken skins, karne norte, the combination silog, and turon a la mode. Kalamansi mimosa was bomb! Cheese sticks with the bacon cheesy dip was bomb! Chicharon with spicy dipping sauce was bomb! Karne norte and combo-silog were both very bomb. Along with the turon a la mode with cotton candy topping with a hint of salt. Bomb!

After we ate I asked Chef Dino how he made the  sawsawan (vinegar sauce) as he explained his method I mentioned we were visiting from Sacramento. After he made a fresh batch, he gave us enough to bring home to share with our family. Aside from that he also sent us off with a sample of his gourmet tuyo (dried fish). Unfortunately our family ate it the next morning before we could get a taste! Alas, their review on the tuyo was pretty epic.

Needless to say we will be back whenever we're in town again.

Thanks Chef Dino and company! You guys rock!
author: ardee t.

description:
A great place for lunch, especially for 2~4 people. 
I ordered Tortang Talong (Filipino eggplant omelet, with spicy nori crisp, bonito flakes, jufran glaze, and garlic fried rice), and it was really delightful. A warm, soothing, and luscious dish. Don't know why, but it made me think about the great smell of the sea--at the "Loja de Peixe Tong Kei," a small dried-fish shop (near the famous Lord Stow's Garden Café,) in Macao. 

推薦"Tortang Talong"-菲律賓式茄子蛋（上有烤海苔、柴魚片，下有香蕉醬、蒜味炒飯），十足令人享受的舒適美味，入口溫潤，調味讓人回味不已。不知為何，也讓我回想起，澳門路環棠記魚鋪，那美好的海味。
author: Anne C.

description:
some o y'all nzas gonna trip when i say 4 stars but y'all need to chill tf out on that where's the bagoong where's the datuputi my mama cooks better well is yo mama here muhfuh is she HERE?? lol jk

new filipino #popup that doesn't stumble over the double dutch ropes bc it ain't super pretentious or too ffffn fusiony.

(^_^) Combination Silog $11 ()
all 3 meats bch (longganisa, tocino, tapa) #twss

(^_^) Tortang Talong $9 ()
egg & jufran beeeeizh

(^_^) Lumpia Shanghai $6.5 ()
dip a bit too tomato cp to how i grew up nbd

might bring my own garlic n extra condiments next time ;p ain't worth it if my breath don't stank after lol.

and i need to figure out the perfect business hours overlap so i can get fried oreos too. #hakunamatata
author: Dan B.

description:
I'm kicking myself for not discovering this place sooner! I took my mom here today for brunch and the food and service was excellent. She had the Carne Norte and I had the Arroz a la Cubana. She loved her dish and so did I. Great portions and tastes. I also had the pineapple mango cooler, and that was fine. 

The hostess was super friendly and so were the rest of the staff. A+ for service. 

We came just before 11:30 AM, and there was no wait. Can't wait to go back again and try their lechon or one of their silogs, I'm sure it'll be great.
author: Maria M.

description: Hospitality at its finest here at Malasa! Their arroz caldo is a must! It reminds me of my childhood. All the silogs are really good, my favorite is the tocino. Make sure you get the Carne Norte, it's really delicious. For drinks, get a mango or calamansi mimosa. I heard that their mango-cantaloupe cooler is also very refreshing. For dessert, get their turon - it's tiny like a lumpia, but still satisfying! Of course, don't skip on the halo-halo. Happy eating!
author: Charlene F.

description: Great spot to get Filipino food and brunch. The cantaloupe juice is definitely something you wanna try  つ _  つ
author: Mallik B.

description:
Can't describe how happy I am that this Filipino brunch place exists. I love how they don't try to reinvent the wheel with their dishes or change the dishes to be something they're not  (sorry vegetarians, no soy longganisa here!), they just somehow made something great even better and stay true to the Filipino flavor.

I ordered the carne Norte which was corned beef with potatoes and garlic rice topped with an egg. DELICIOUS. Not too salty, not swimming in fat or oil, no squishy potatoes, all was perfect. 

My friends ordered the tocino and the tortang talong. Both were spot on.  

The mango cantaloupe cooler was so refreshing and came with refills! This stuff was fresh, you can see them squeezing up the cantaloupe. 

But what really makes the place are the owners. You can tell they've put a lot of thought in the menu and a lot of pride in the food they serve. She has asked "so does this pass the Filipino test?" yup it definitely does! Will definitely be back and dragging all of my friends with me.
author: Crystal M.

description:
I had walked right past it trying to find it the first time since it was inside Craw Station so the sign wasn't that big. First time here. A bit on the pricey side compared to other Filipino restaurants I've been to but the food was delicious! 

Appetizers- lumpia and fish balls. However I think other places tend to have more lumpia in an order

Entree- smoked trout, carne Norte and their pork belly. All was delicious, but definitely recommend the later two. 

Others- also got their calamansi juice and ube ice cream (tho the photo shows 1 scoop but they give u 3 scoops . we didn't get the halo halo since we wouldn't be able to finish it)

Definitely recommend
author: serene h.

description: Such a good brunch spot! My friend got the Cubano plate and it came with cotton candy sprinkled with paprika, rice, and ground beef with some super good sauce. I ordered the lechon kawali and it was pretty good! The first time the food came out there was a hair on it, but I told the waiter and it got replaced. The pork belly was a little cold in the center, but the skin was crispy and the garlic rice was DELICIOUS. The cut I got was pretty fatty so there wasn't a lot of meat, but the rice was delicious and the presentation was nice.
author: Kim N.

description: This wknd pop-up in my neighborhood is definitely worth trying (and venturing to if you're not in our hood). My group and I were all fans of everything we ate (minus the lumpia which we kinda wish was a lil crispier and had more flavor. they should also try a diff sauce for the dipping). They seemed a bit overwhelmed today which made sense because the service was SUPER slow (for a party of 3, it took us just over 2.5hrs after being seated to get all of our food - 3apps and 3entrees, drinks - calamansi mimosas which were comp'd due to the long wait, dessert - which was comp'd due to the long wait, and the check). The flavor of all the dishes were so unique, delicious, and perfectly executed (i just wanted to sound like a judge on top chef) and the staff were very friendly despite the chaos. We will definitely be going back for brunch again soon!
author: Jason F.

description:
Pleased to have this filipino brunch place nearby, now I have an excuse NOT to cook breakfast/brunch at home. And it's even more of a plus that whatever you order from Malasa is a feast for the eyes as well....Beautifully plated entrees!!! Hurray! Who says Pinoy food needs to be a greasy hodge podge packed on overflowing rice? 

MALASA is the perfect place to go to when you want a quiet relaxing Filipino breakfast....and the coffee is good too!!!
author: Jackie A.

description:
As a Filipino American, it can be challenging to find Filipino food in the City done right. There are good places in San Bruno, South SF, and San Mateo, but in SF, it's been hit & miss with some places trying too hard by deconstructing traditional Filipino dishes that compromise flavor with trendy or "mainstream" ingredients.

Malasa, the pop-up at Craw Station on Ninth Ave. near Irving does an incredible job maintaining the integrity of traditional flavors with additional flair. From the classic "Silog" family of Filipino breakfast or the Arroz Caldo (rice porridge) to the tender Carne Norte (corn beef hash), Chef Dino and Ro knows what they are doing.

If you've never tried Filipino food or if you are particular about how yours is prepared, I highly recommend giving Malasa a try.
author: A. M.

description:
Filipino cuisine may be new to some people, but to others it's a part of their identity. I for one am of Filipino decent, but born and raised in SF. I grew up eating Filipino food and it's refreshing to see that more and more restaurants are opening across SF in recent days. 

Malasa does a great job in integrating Filipino traditional dishes with familiar ingredients. You won't find caviar, purple flowers, dancing bonita flakes, or spicy nori crips in my grandma's home made dishes. These ingredients just pose a great addition to the traditional dishes and elevates it to culminate into a unique meal. 

I highly recommend ordering Arroz Caldo and Silog Combination plate. Arroz Caldo is essentially a rice porridge similar to congee.The flavors of chicken, garlic, egg, and a hint of lemon juice come together in a bowl of awesomeness. It's a tasty warm soup that fills the heart with every spoonful. Moving on to the next recommended dish, the Silog combination plate. Here you get three meats with rice, egg, and a pickled slaw. This combo plate includes Tapa (beef), Tocino (sweet pork), and Longanisa (sweet sausage). The meat is marinated with amazing flavor and you could tell there were no short cuts in making this dish. Here's a little tip that may tickle your fancy. Dig your fork in a piece of meat, dip the meat in vinegar and pair it with a spoonful of rice and egg. Here you got yourself a party in your mouth. You're very welcome. 

The Chef at Malasa is super awesome and is hard at work in getting the Filipino Cuisine out there. He truly values his customers and I've had the pleasure in talking to him a couple of times. One thing that he shared with me is that he's thrilled to see plates clean and empty because it means that you really enjoyed the meal. I sure do each and every time! Come on in on a Saturday or Sunday morning for brunch and clean out your plate! Enjoy! :)
author: Briana H.

description: The food is inventive and traditional in flavors. I had the tapsilog, fish balls, halo halo and chicken skin chicharon sooooo yummy . My friend had the home made carne Norte oh my life changer !
author: Gretchen J.

description: Awesome food with great service and hospitality. The place is always busy so you might have to wait for your food a little longer than you want to depending on the time of service. We had the crispy chicken fries, smoked trout with caviar and garlic rice, and the carne Norte. The beef was outstanding. Their mango-guava juice was refreshing and great way to wash the food down and they offer free refills as well. The food has a unique fusion kind of blend of spices, hotness, and sweetness. The best thing about them are the presentations and the fusion ideas. Their jackfruit banana egg rolls (hot of the pan) deepfried with ice cream over it melted right into the mouth.
author: Himadri Shekhar K.

description: I've been here twice and had positive experience both times. The owners are super friendly. The food is an extra flavorful Filipino food. The green sauce gives everything an extra kick.
author: Aureen A.

description: So glad to have a filipino spot in the neighborhood. Chef Dino puts so much care in the food that he puts out. The food was amazing, i would recommend getting the Carne Norte (not your lola's corned beef silog ok) and the Arroz caldo. The mango coolers are delicious too. I would pass on the basic (yes i said it) silogs and try the specials instead. Also note, sometimes the food can take a minute so order the lumpia while you wait. I need to come again to see if theyve cut down on the wait time but then again Rome wasnt built in a day. I would still recommend!
author: Margarita M.

description: The tinapang bangus (milkfish) was great! Very good and the presentation was beautiful. People working there are also very nice.
author: Adrien P.

description:
Highly anticipated, but just ok. I'm not Filipino, so I can't speak to the authenticity of this spot, but my arroz a la cubana wasn't as flavorful than I thought it would be, and while the cotton candy was a nice touch in terms of aesthetics and effort, I didn't think it paired that well with the dish taste-wise. 

It also took my friend at least 2-3 attempts to get a refill on coffee, so I wasn't blown away by the service either.  

Overall, it's fine, but I don't need to go back.
author: Rob L.

description: The brunch was absolutely delicious and very authentic. To start we had the fish balls which were perfectly crispy and were paired with a delicious savory sauce. We also had the lumpia Shanghai, and the chicken chicharon. All the apps were prefecly cooked, were paired with delicious dipping sauces, and we would order them again! For our meals we had the combination silog, the carne Norte, and the lechon kawali. The portions were very generous and the meats were all very flavorful. I especially loved the langanisa . We washed our meals down with delicious house mango pineapple juice. Malasa was a perfect location for Saturday morning brunch with friends and we would put it at the top of our recommendation list! If you have never had Philipino breakfast this is the perfect place to try it. You will not be disappointed!
author: Jessica S.

description:
The tastiest brunch (meal in general) that I've had in a long time, where everyone at the table felt it was money well spent. I'm so glad to have stumbled upon Malasa. 

We ordered the arroz caldo, carne norte, smoked trout (delicious bites when all components on the dish are mixed together), and meat combo for food, along with a variety of tropical juice for drinks - I left with an even better impression of Filipino cuisine. 

Every dish was memorable and I would go back / recommend to friends & family without hesitation. The space is good for parties of all sizes, with an indoor dining area (that was slightly too breezy) and a patio in the back.
author: Ack J.

description: The food is 5 stars. I've tried almost everything on the menu. Favorites are: smoked trout and tocino. Everything is perfectly seasoned and beautifully presented. Only gripe is it takes a while for the food to come out but it's worth it. If I could lick the plate I would.
author: Grace H.

description: Our family is always looking for a new place to eat so we found this place and tried it. Their food is amazing especially the chicken chicharon, longganisa, arroz caldo, carne norte. And most of all service was amazing. Anyone reading this I suggest to try this place!!!! The whole family went home full and happy. Planning to go!!!!!
author: Aurora M.

description:
Great addition to the neighborhood. Grew up eating silog. Garlic rice with an egg, my go to comfort food. If you never had Filipino food, go for that tapa, if you like sweet go for Tocino.

Maybe in the future they'll add dinuguan and kare kare
author: Robin L.

description:
Filipina here and I love the food here at Malasa. 

Malasa (which means "tasty" in Tagalog) is one of the better silog places I've had in the city. Actually, I don't think I've ever really eaten at a Filipino restaurant in the city itself.. always outside in Daly City/San Bruno area. I've been here 2x w/ my boyfriend and we've loved the food both times we've gone -- the food is delicious w/ all the Filipino taste done right, it's beautifully presented, and staff is super friendly! What more can you ask for?

So far here's what we've ordered:
(1st) - Combo Silog - tapa, longanisa, tocino + this perfectly fried egg. YUM!
        - Arroz Caldo - deliciousness comfort food. The fried garlic bits are just amazing. 
        - Halo-Halo (w/ lychee jelly. that's a first for me, I think)
        - Fried Chicken Skin - ommmmmgggggg it's perfect and the sauce that comes with is has the right amount of heat, sour, salty all combined. Watch your cholesterol levels though if you eat this cuz you won't be able to eat just 1 piece
        - Calamansi Juice - absolute perfection
        - Mango/Pineapple Juice - too sweet but I still drank it

(2nd) - Tapsilog (just the tapa this time)
         - Arroz Caldo (again)
         - Calamansi Mimosa - honestly, it wasn't very good. I'd stick to just the calamansi juice on it's own
         - Fried Chicken Skin - seriously you should get it. you won't regret it. 
         - Red Horse Beer - this is boozy for breakfast but it's my go-to when I am in the Philippines so it's nice to see it being sold in restaurants


I'm really happy that this place opened up so close to my boyfriend's apartment. He better believe I will be dragging him here atleast once every couple of weeks.
author: Jocelle A.

description:
Awesome and approved from a Filipino 
Will be a repeat or continue to be a repeat since I've been going here for crawstation. 

Had carne Norte, sampler plate, halo halo all good! 

Service, wonderful!
author: Richard C.

description:
WOW! The food here is amazing! And the halo-halo is to die for! I was craving for Filipino breakfast and wanted to try someplace new. The place is nice and clean. They only serve brunch, so the menu is limited. It's more just breakfast. None of those main Filipino dishes. 

*I tried the fried chicken skin - crispy and so addicting! It wasn't greasy at all. And the sauce went perfectly well with it. Definitely get this one! You won't regret it.

*Then I ordered the combination plate, which included the tocino, tapa, and longganisa. Whenever I eat these dishes anywhere else, they're pretty much just the frozen ones you can buy at the store (for the tocino and longganisa). But in this place, it actually tastes like it's made from scratch. Very good! And the salted egg & tomato complimented the meal well.

*And you gotta get the halo-halo, best one I've ever had! 

I'm Filipino and a picky Filipino food eater. I tend to usually cook Filipino dishes on my own because the ones in the restaurants tend to be too oily or salty. That's why I'm so excited to have found this place! I will definitely be back. Can't wait to try everything on their menu!
author: Kristine A.

description: I really loved the combination plate where it served longanisa, beef tapa, and Tocino. The fried egg was cooked perfectly with the garlic rice. As a person growing up eating Filipino food the meal I ate still taste like home but even better. No fusion needed. It was well presented, workers and the owner presented beyond great service. I would definitely come back!
author: Rodel S.

description: The brunch is amazing.  Had the porridge this morning after the farmers market and was pleasantly surprised.  Had always come here for the seafood but never thought to try the brunch menu.  Topped it off with the mimosa and I was done.  The porridge was very reasonably priced.  5.25$ maybe a tad bit underpriced but I won't tell them that.  Good job chef Dino!
author: Duy N.

description: Wow!! This was an amazing experience. Stumbled upon here by walking through the streets. I would give 6stars for the food if possible!
author: Sami B.

description: We loved the food here so much, we came 3 weekends consecutively! The brunch food really hits the spot. My favorites are the Carne Norte (corned beef) land the Tortang Talong (roasted eggplant with scrambled egg and bonito flakes). The Chef, Dino, is so friendly and his partner, Roh (sp?) was so fun to chat with.
author: Connie H.

description: Excellent brunch. Ordered the trio meat platter which came with marinated pork, beef, and sausage. The sausage was my favorite - succulent and flavorful. The tableside black pepper, garlic, and vinegar sauce was DELICIOUS. As someone who loves all three ingredients I used up half the bottle because it paired well with everything on my plate.
author: Courtney C.

description: I was so excited to hear about a Filipino pop-up in the west side of the city! I opted for the traditional filipino breakfast with longganisa (this is a sausage with very similar profile to linguica or chorizo). It did not disappoint; the accompanying garlic rice and egg were spot-on as well. My only issue is that the dish is a bit small--c'mon this is Filipino food, portions are supposed to be large!
author: Benjamin A.

description: Love the brunch offerings here. Everything was on point and the service was friendly and attentive.
author: Eric C.

description: This was a pleasant surprise for our family while out seeking a good weekend brunch place near GG Park. It is a pop-up Filipino cuisine only on weekends when it substitutes for a crawfish place that has been here for a few years. The food is tasty and reasonably priced, especially for this area.
author: Rod D.

description: I wanted to comment on how friendly the service was at Malasa! I enjoyed the food there and thought that the price was very reasonable! I also liked that the dishes were well plated! I would highly recommend the Tortang Talong for vegetarians and for meat lovers, try the combination platter!Definitely give the place a try! :)
author: Claire S.

description: The food here is really flavorful. I got the combination silog plate and still haven't decided what I liked the most. Some of the best homemade (hot) sauces too. Will totally be visiting again
author: Pravin P.

description: I love pop-ups. And when you get one in your neighborhood serving delicious Filipino food, it's such a win. This was my second time at Malasa and the food is still super yummy and filling, with one huge improvement: the service. Last time I came everything was crazy late but they were kind enough to comp our drinks. This time the service matched the quality of the food. I had the tocino silog and my husband had the longanisa silog, both came w a perfectly cooked egg on top. We both came home with leftovers. We also had the cheese sticks w bacon aioli (sooooo good, they use American cheese and when you dip the sticks in what is essentially bacon fat it's so addictive) and the chicken chicharrones w their house made hot sauce, which I wish they would bottle and sell. It's the perfect heat level without losing good flavor. If I had one criticism, it's their mimosas. The price is right ($6) but both juice mixers are off. Wish they'd do a basic oj option. All in all a totally satisfying brunch and feels good to support a local pop-up - thanks, Malasa!
author: Michelle P.

description: I don't reccomend this place. We left because clearly the service was poor and we stood and waited to get seated even when there were empty tables that just needed to be bussed.
author: Joan Z.

description: I've only gone once, but it was really yummy and the people who work there are very friendly! I had the home made chiccharon and loved it!
author: Sharon T.

description:
Masala is a pop up that is inside of Craw Station on Saturday and Sunday mornings.

The food is GREAT. The ingredients are of quality. The flavors are original and thoughtfully balanced. The presentation is great as well. Whoever creates the menu clearly cares about food, and it definitely shows in their final product. It is authentic filipino food but much healthier and cleaner than usually presented and also with a modern twist.

I've been here 3 times in the past 2 months since discovering it to try different items on their menu. These are my favorite menu items so far: 

-crispy chicken chicharon 
omggg BEST Chicharon i've ever had. I love that its chicken instead of the typical pork. It was much thinner (which means crispier!) and less greasy than I'm used to. It came out warm w/ housemade hot sauce. The hot sauce is to die for. I would buy bottles of it if it were available. 

-tortang talong 
Generous portions. If you're a fan of Torta, this is just so tasty. This is probably my current go-to 

-carne norte 
I only had a few bites of this but  from what I had it was really good. Savory and comforting. Great for the meat lovers. 

-smoked trout
Portion is smaller but really beautiful presentation really fancy ingredients in there. 

This has easily become my favorite brunch spot in Inner Sunset, and I've been living on Irving for 3 years. I just had it this morning and I'm craving it already.
author: Sam T.

description: A pop up Filipino restaurant around Judah/Irving area. Finding a parking spot was a bit of a challenge specially on a Sunday. This pop up shares the space with Crawstation.  Entire staff were very friendly and attentive. We ordered two of the Carne Norte and one Tortang Talong. The Carne Norte, house made corned beef brisket with potatoes and onions served on garlic rice is a Filipino classic breakfast dish. Of course what Filipino dish without a fried egg on top?  This type of Filipino food is generally called Silog (sinangag which is basically fried rice - typically garlic rice - and itlog which is a fried egg). You can't go wrong with corned beef. It was very tasty (malasa as translated in Tagalog).  I can't remember the last time I had Tortang Talong so I just had to have it. My mom used to make this dish by grilling the eggplant first, and then adding fried ground pork to make a tasty omelette. Malasa's Tortang Talong was vegetarian option. It was served with nori and bonito flakes on top, banana ketchup sauce on the side. The banana ketchup may throw you off if you haven't had it before. It's a slightly sweeter version of a ketchup and goes well with this dish. Overall we were very satisfied with our food. Would totally come back again and hope this pop up could end up becoming a mainstay!
author: Merlyn A.

description: This is a great brunch restaurant! Although the food came out a little slow (which they warned us about because of a larger party in front of us) they had unmatchable customer service and great tasting food! I appreciate how much this restaurant made an effort to make sure we loved their food and had a great time!! I would definitely come back! (-:
author: Alyx J.

description:
**Reposted from my review on the Crawstation page. Malasa has it's own yelp page now!**

The Filipino breakfast here is incredible. Hands down the best brunch in the inner sunset-- I'm here every weekend and step by step getting all of my friends and family addicted to the goodness here. My dining companions leave rave reviews as well.

It's hard enough to find Filipino food in SF proper, and the popup here is one of the best renditions of Filipino breakfast I've had. Not too greasy, tons of flavor with the really carefully selected ingredients, and comforting as can be. Their presentation is also beautiful-- bonus points for that. Not sure what else you would want in a brunch. 

I almost always order the arroz caldo, which is the perfect breakfast for any mood. Super flavorful with the brown butter chicken and perfect amount of ginger and green onion, perfectly soothing in it's porridgey texture, definitely my go-to here. The silogs are also the ideal breakfast. You get garlic rice for your carbs, lovingly made meats (recommend the tocino) for your protein, a crispy egg for happiness, and dipping vinegar and pickled green papaya to really take it over the edge of tasty.

They are constantly adding new items to the menu-- recent faves include the chicken chicharron and the astonishing new trout silog (got to try it during testing, an amazing mouthful of sous vide egg, roe, rice and smoked trout). And the folks here are actually the nicest, you'll leave smiling because your belly is full of joy and you had the loveliest chat while you were stuffing your face.

I want you guys to go so that the popup becomes permanent and they start making Filipino foods during dinner too. But also, you should go because it's amazing and you'll be happy.
author: Lydia J.

description: Great Filipino brunch! Good portions, creative and high quality! Would definitely recommend!
author: eric c.

description:
happy to find elevated filipino food. starting with all the positives: the longganisa-silog and the smoked trout dish we ordered tasted as great as it looked. we also ordered some fish balls and the sriracha sauce was good. for dessert we ordered the classic halo halo can't really go wrong with that one. 

criticism:  
-we waited for our table longer than necessary. the two top was available but they decided they would seat everyone else ahead of us before seating us. they did apologize for making us wait for 40mins. 
-when our food arrive, it was cold. I would have expected the garlic fried rice to be at least warm but it was not. 
-my smoked trout had at least 12 small fish bones.
-they ran out of items on the menu and we were not told until we ordered. would been really disappointing after waiting all that time and not have anything to choose from because of dietary restriction 
-a pen used for the wait list sign-in fell into a pitcher of water, we notified the servers and the pitcher of water was never changed out.

conclusion: I'm excited that filipino cuisine is present in the scene but would like the fixable items to be addressed. the food is really delicious so really would like this pop-up to be a regular spot in the sf food scene.
author: Pamela M.

description: The Best Filipino Brunch! We had the Carne Norte and Kare Kare! Service is amazing Dino and the team are awesome, very warm and friendly atmosphere. I wish it was an everyday brunch . Will definitely come back!
author: Winona M.

description: Love the food. You will get the real taste of filipino food. Nothing greasy, serve fresh and hot. The smelt is crispy outside, fresh and soft inside. Service is great. Friendly staff just like how the culture should be. The taste of silogs and tortang talong is just what we are really craving for.   This is the best filipino restaurant in SF. Portions are big enough to feed your hungry stomach.
author: Luisa B.

description:
The food presentation is good but taste not so much.

We ordered the following
Crispy chicken skin - probably the best thing we ordered.
Longanisa - Rice is bland and undercooked.
Smoked trout - salty, tough to eat. 

Service was also condescending.

Overall there are much better Filipino restaurants in the city.
author: Jon S.

description: Excellent tocino and longanisa! Will definitely be back to try their tapa and the halo-halo. So great to have Filipino food without having to travel to Daly City!
author: Pauline G.

description: Malasa's food embody all the tingly sensation a Pilipino dish usually does. The food is cooked just right. We had the combo platter which was incredible and drank Mimosas. Make sure to arrive here before 2 to get the best experience.
author: Hamza H.

description: It was great, I loved it! I tried combination and it was really good, but the calamansi was a bit too calm. The owner also gave us free shots.
author: Kelvin O.

description: Delicious Philippino food with homemade sauces and marinated meats. Definitely going back.
author: Robyn L.

description: Nice place and friendly staff for weekend brunch. Great new option and addition to the neighborhood.
author: Dom B.

description: This is my favorite place for Filipino brunch! My friend and I were looking for a good brunch place and we found Masala. We were seated right away and our server, Will was the best. He was super attentive and funny. The food came quick and was delicious. Will definitely come back again!
author: Alex C.

description: WARNING: This is not your typical filipino restaurant! But the food here is amazing! The Kare-kare is a must have in this place! They have great service and very welcoming!
author: Joshua U.

description: We went there based on such a good rating but left with big disappointment. First of all I don't think the hostess knew how to treat customers. We didn't feel we were welcomed there. Maybe she only likes "certain" people. The beef was dry. The rice was certainly leftover, dry and chunky. Be careful when you chew it! This place is way overrated.
author: Jane W.
